title: How to Recycle a Light Bulb

methods.name: Following Protocol for the Type of Light Bulb

steps.headline: Bring LED light bulbs to specialized recycling centers or a local retail store.
steps.description: While it’s a bit harder to find recycling centers that accept LED light bulbs, there are options such as a specific recycling centers or a local retail store. Search online for a local spot to bring your LED lights to by typing "LED light bulb recycling places near me" or something similar into your search bar. LED Christmas lights are the most accepted type of LED light when it comes to recycling.

steps.headline: Avoid placing any type of light bulb in your curbside recycling bin.
steps.description: Even if your type of light bulb is recyclable, never place the light bulbs in your recycling bin. Not only can they break easily, but they contain so many different materials that regular recycling sorting machines can’t separate the pieces properly.

steps.headline: Place incandescent or halogen bulbs in the trash because they can’t be recycled.
steps.description: These types of bulbs contain hazardous material and can’t be recycled because it would be too complicated to separate all of their parts. Wrap the bulb in newspaper or another material so it doesn’t break when you put it in the trash. Don’t try to place incandescent bulbs or halogen bulbs with your glass to be recycled. The bulbs are made of a different type of glass and won’t be accepted.

steps.headline: Check the Household Hazardous Waste rules if you have fluorescent bulbs.
steps.description: Fluorescent lights, also called CFLs, have small amounts of mercury in them which make them hazardous. While some recycling centers or stores may accept CFLs, check the rules about recycling this type of bulb with your local recycling and hazardous waste regulations to make sure you’re doing it safely. First look up the Household Hazardous Waste guidelines for your area online to see what they require in regards to CFLs. Call your local recycling center to ask if they accept fluorescent light bulbs. Some states require by law that you bring your CFL bulbs to a facility.

steps.headline: Bring your light bulbs to a local retailer if they accept your type of bulb.
steps.description: Many hardware stores like Home Depot and Lowe’s have light bulb recycling programs. Go online or call ahead to find out if they accept your type of bulb, and bring the light bulb into the store to recycle it. Ace Hardware is another store that often accepts light bulbs. Sites like Earth911 can tell you which stores accept each kind of light bulb.

steps.headline: Check your local recycling center’s website to see if they accept your bulbs.
steps.description: There’s likely a recycling center near you that takes light bulbs. If you search online and find one, remember that you’ll need to bring the light bulbs to the specific recycling location instead of using a curbside service.

steps.headline: Use an online recycling search tool to find other nearby drop-off options.
steps.description: The best online search tools for figuring out how to recycle your light bulbs (or any other material!) are Earth911 and Recycle Nation. These two sites let you type in the object you’re trying to recycle along with your location and give you nearby recycling locations to take your light bulbs to. Type in your specific kind of light bulb into the site’s search bar for the most helpful results.

steps.headline: Mail your light bulbs in to a recycler if there isn’t one near you.
steps.description: This is a good option if there aren’t any retail stores or recycling centers in your area that accept your specific type of bulb. Choose a mail-back service where you send in your light bulbs, often paying a small fee for shipping. There’s a list of companies that accept light bulbs by mail on the EPA website at https://www.epa.gov/cfl/recycling-and-disposal-cfls-and-other-bulbs-contain-mercury#mail.

steps.headline: Know the rules and regulations regarding light bulb disposal in your area.
steps.description: Several states and local jurisdictions have special laws for how you should dispose of your light bulbs—especially if you have fluorescent ones. Go online to find out if there are any rules in your area about how you need to recycle or throw away your light bulbs. For example, some states require you to bring fluorescent bulbs to a hazardous waste center because they aren't supposed to be put in the trash or recycling. Disposing of light bulbs properly helps protect the earth while keeping sanitation workers safe too.
